nodes.bodyText: It would be nice to add a single-sentence Javadoc to each of these explaining what they do. Others might find them useful in the future;
Done.

This is very inefficient. If you call this in a tight loop, then this will take a long time (due to constant reinitialization). Can you have this method take another argument that indicates how many events to write? Even if you don't use it now, someone in the future might find that useful.
PS: if you do that, no need to call .get() upon each .writeEvent. Collect the futures in a list, and use Futures.allOf(...).get().
PS2: A timeout for that .get might be useful too to pass to this method. But your call.
Sure, I've made the change in the latest commit I just pushed.

Same here. If you read just 1 message, this is OK. But as soon as you want to read more, then this method will be very slow.
Consider taking a count argument and returning an (ordered) list of Strings representing the events.
Have made this change as suggested.

It may surprise you but on Travis, this timeout may not be sufficient. Expect this to be a root cause for random failures.
If the timeout expires, you won't get a TimeoutException; rather the getEvent() will return null, which will likely manifest as a NullPtrEx upstream.
I've increased the timeout to account for that.
You already used SneakyThrows in this class. You might as well use it here too.
Done.

false is returned when the stream already exists.
so in the idempotent case, do you want to throw the exception from here or return the boolean from this method signature to let the caller know so that they can deal with it.
Sure, I've modified the implementation to return a boolean that indicates whether all the objects were newly created or not.

in case of a checkpoint event, you could get a null event.
i think you should add event only when it is not a checkpoint event.
or disable checkpoint in the readergroup config.
otherwise that can lead to some tests to fail.

We are assuming that the checkpoint is disabled in the reader group:

  
    
      pravega/test/integration/src/main/java/io/pravega/test/integration/utils/TestUtils.java
    
    
        Lines 161 to 164
      in
      4788434
    
    
    
    

        
          
           ReaderGroupConfig readerGroupConfig = ReaderGroupConfig.builder() 
        

        
          
                   .stream(Stream.of(scope, stream)) 
        

        
          
                   .disableAutomaticCheckpoints() 
        

        
          
                   .build();
we can simply use a writer.flush() here.
Thanks. That change makes the code much simpler. I've made the change as suggested.

Since the reader group is not deleted invoking readDataFromStream(..) again would cause the method to read the next events from the stream. So we should document this behaviour or perhaps invoke delete reader group or change the name of the method to convey this behaviour perhaps as readNextEvents(..)
Sure, I've renamed the methods, so that they better represent the behavior that these methods exhibit.
typo.
Great catch - truly a hard to find one! I've fixed it now.
new ClustuerWrapper() will ensure the defaults are not used. Should we make the default constructor private to enforce the builder pattern?
Sure, I've now made the change to prevent instantiation using the default constructor.
Does this @builder generate a seperate builder?

It generates a builder for the ControllerWrapper based on the parameters used in this Constructor (as opposed to the Class-level annotation we use in the ClusterWrapper). The idea was to avoid interface changes to ControllerWrapper so that the many tests that use it don't need to change.
